title: (x) "Scum" outlined uncial - Manuscript Caps {Lex}
content:
Can anybody identify this font? Thanks

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [font.JPG](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040600/http:/typophile.com/files/font.JPG) | 20.41 KB |

 [‹ (x) Fiorentina Jersey name and numerals - Stencil, Times {Dav, Yves}](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040600/http:/www.typophile.com/node/17274 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Curves logo - similar to Sarah Script {Stephen, Yves} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040600/http:/www.typophile.com/node/17208 "Go to next forum topic")
author: theterrible

comments.content:
I’m sure I have this in my old Letraset catalogue (at work;( )

The name Marvin springs to mind.

Richard

’ [Acadian](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040600/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/scriptorium/acadian/)’ and ’Edison’ may be alternates  
_( Or even ’ [Kilkenny](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040600/http:/www.p22.com/ihof/kilkenny.html)’, by fellow Typophile Paul Hunt )_

Dav

Thanks for both responses, Acadian is indeed pretty similar. I looked through a newer Letraset catalogue and didn’t see anything similar, or Marvin; Richard, if you happen to be at work next to the catalogue and think of this post, I’d love to hear.

<cite>( Or even ‘Kilkenny’, by fellow Typophile Paul Hunt )</cite>

You bastard!

I’ve got an old Letraset catalogue. Richard was close. It’s “Manuscript Caps” - located directly above “Marvin” :) The ’S’ has been modified / is an alternate not in my book.

- Lex

Hi Lex, just in the process posting this image

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040600im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/manscript.jpg)
  
I was close!

I remembered where else I had seen it, on the (original UK) cover of [Black Sabbath’s](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040600/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_Sabbath_%28album%29) eponymous first album in 1970, complete with alternate S

Richard

’Spire’, I dont quite get your ’_You bastard!_’ remark  
_Do you dare to explain ? Thanks_

Dav

Dav:

It was a reference to a recurring joke on the animated TV show [<cite>South Park</cite>](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040600/http:/www.comedycentral.com/shows/south_park/).

There is a character named Kenny who often gets killed in a humorous and grisly manner (only to be resurrected without explanation in the next episode). Whenever Kenny is killed, the following dialogue ensues between his friends:

**Stan** : Oh my God! You killed Kenny!  
**Kyle** : You bastard!

Sorry about that.

Edward

Noo, I am sorry, I get it now :)  
_’Kill Kenny’, Aarrgghh, I didnt even think about that_

Dav
